hints.content:
Let's think about each statement to see whether it is true.

We read the multiplication table from left to right and from top to bottom.

###Each number has a $0$ or $5$ in the ones place.

$\begin{align}
5&=0\text{ tens}+5\text{ ones}\\\\
10&=1\text{ tens}+0\text{ ones}\\\\
15&=1\text{ tens}+5\text{ ones}\\\\
20&=2\text{ tens}+0\text{ ones}\\\\
25&=2\text{ tens}+5\text{ ones}\\\\
30&=3\text{ tens}+0\text{ ones}\\\\
35&=3\text{ tens}+5\text{ ones}\\\\
40&=4\text{ tens}+0\text{ ones}\\\\
45&=4\text{ tens}+5\text{ ones}\\\\
50&=5\text{ tens}+0\text{ ones}
\end{align}$

This statement is true.

###Each number has a $0$ or $5$ in the tens place.

The number $5$ has a $0$ in the tens place. The next number, $10$, has a $1$ in the tens place.

This statement is not true.

###The ones digit and the tens digit of each number add up to a multiple of $5$.

The number $5$ has $0$ tens and $5$ ones. Its digits add up to $5$.

The number $10$ has $1$ ten and $0$ ones. Its digits add up to $1$. The number $1$ is not a multiple of $5$.

This statement is not true.

This statement is true:

- Each number has a $0$ or $5$ in the ones place.

question.content:
**Which statement describes a pattern in the shaded parts of the multiplication table?**

![Multiplication table with the column and row labeled 5 shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/231e913873fdeaee9cef316d0870843428244d68)

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: Each shaded number has a $0$ or $5$ in the ones place.
Each shaded number has a $0$ or $5$ in the tens place.
The ones digit and the tens digit of each shaded number add up to a multiple of $5$.
